caseTitle: MATTER OF REX VERSUS THEOPHILUS ADENUGA TUNW
summary: This 1935 West African Court of Appeal decision, delivered by Acting Chief Justice Cor. Butler-Lloyd, addressed an application for bail pending appeal by Theophilus Adenuga Tunw Ashe, the former Awujale of Ijebu Ode, who had been convicted and sentenced to four years' imprisonment on multiple counts under the Criminal Code. The application was made under Section 17(2) of the West African Court of Appeal Ordinance (No. 47 of 1933). The court denied bail, emphasizing that bail pending appeal is only granted in exceptional circumstances or where undue delay in hearing the appeal would result in a substantial portion of the sentence being served. The court found that a two-month delay relative to a four-year sentence did not meet this threshold. Reference was made to prior cases, including Rex v Lawrence and Rex v Riegels, to illustrate distinguishing factors such as legal uncertainty or the need for client-counsel communication, which were absent here. The ruling reaffirmed judicial restraint in bail decisions to maintain consistency in future cases.
legalKeywords: West African Court of Appeal Ordinance
citations: West African Court of Appeal Ordinance 47 of 1933, s 17(2)
Rex v Gott, C.A. Reports Vol. XVI
rationaleHighlights: Bail pending appeal requires exceptional circumstances or undue delay
Two-month delay not significant relative to four-year sentence
No legal uncertainty or procedural complexity justifying bail
Precedents distinguish cases with stated cases or short sentences
Free communication between client and counsel not a factor here
Sentences run concurrently but total length still relevant
Court exercises restraint to avoid setting inconsistent precedent
